input.value: What is your full name?

generated: Shiki, Natsume.
generated_no_rag: My full name is Shiki Natsume.
generated_ollama: That would be Shiki Natsume, at your service! *smirks slightly*
generated_ollama_with_rag: That's a simple question, isn't it? *stares* My full name is Shiki Natsume. Nice to share that with you.
rag_results: Kousei: Morning, everyone. Suzune: Hey. Kanna: Good morning, Takamine-san. Kousei: How are the Yule Logs coming along? Suzune: We're about 80\% done, I think. Kousei: Is there anything I can help with? Suzune: Wanna start prepping the cheesecakes for me? You remember how to do it, don't you? Kousei: Yeah. Kanna: I'll help out as well. Just tell me what to do. Kousei: Aren't you helping with the Yule Logs, though? Kanna: We've already finished rolling them into log-shapes. All that's left is to add the external decorations, but only Suzune-san is skilled enough to do that. Suzune: I'll be fine. You can go ahead and help him. Kousei: Alright. Mei: Whoa! An actual Yule Log! It looks absolutely scrumptious! Nozomi: Are you finished making them? Suzune: For today, at least. Phew... My shoulders are killing me. Kanna: I'm not surprised. You had to put the finishing touches on all of them. Natsume: Well, they certainly turned out great. Thanks for all your hard work. Kousei: We're not very busy right now, so feel free to take a break if you want, Suzune-san. Suzune: Thanks. I'll take you up on that then. Kanna: Of course. Natsume: Now then, let's get these cakes boxed up. Nozomi & Mei: Okaaay! Mei: Welcome to Cafe Stella! Party of two? If you'd rather not wait, we do have a couple counter seats available right now. Would that be alright? Nozomi: Welcome to Cafe Stella! Ah, you placed an order for two Yule Logs under the name Ota? I'll have them ready for you in just a moment. Natsume: Two pancakes, a blend coffee, and a Guatemalan coffee? I'll have those right out to you. Natsume: Two coffees; house blend and Guatemalan, please. Mikado: Coming right up. Kanna: Oh, Natsume-san! I need to go fetch some more Yule Logs from the kitchen. Can you cover for me while I'm gone? Natsume: I'll go fetch them instead. I need to put in another order anyway. Kanna: Alright, that'd be great. Thank you. Kanna: I apologize for the delay, sir. We'll have them ready in just a minute, so please be patient. Natsume: Order coming in. Two plates of pancakes, please. Kousei: Got it. Suzune: How are the Yule Logs selling? Natsume: Fairly well. Most of the customers who've placed advance orders have arrived to pick them up too. Suzune: Phew. That's a relief... Kousei: Were you that worried? Suzune: Well, yeah. I don't know if they're pranks or what, but sometimes you'll get large orders and then the customer never comes to pick it up. Kousei: That kind of stuff actually happens? I've read stories online, but it's scary how easy it is for a single person to screw you over. Suzune: Fortunately, it doesn't look like that's the case this time. Suzune: Anyway, back to work. Pancakes, was it? Kousei: Yeah. I'll handle them. Suzune: You will? Well, okay. Natsume: I'd better get these Yule Logs delivered too. Suzune: I'll help you carry them. I want to see how our customers are doing anyway. Mei: Welcome to Cafe Stella! Miyama: Hello again. Mei: Oh? You're Yuina-chan's--ah, I beg your pardon. Hello there, Mister Miyama. Miyama: Oh, you don't need to be so formal. Miyama: Actually, I'm also here to pick up a cake that I ordered. Mei: A Yule Log, yes? Wait right here; I'll have it out to you in one moment. Suzune: Welcome. Miyama: Hello again. I just can't ignore your cakes, they're so good. Miyama: My daughter's been looking forward to this for a while too. She says no other cake shop will do. Suzune: I'm flattered. I sincerely hope it's to your liking. Miyama: Oh, no need to worry about that. I'm confident it will be every bit as delicious as all the others I've had before. I'm looking forward to it as well. Suzune: Thank you very much. Your praise means a lot to me. Miyama: Oh, and before I forget. Could I also get some shortcakes, fruit tarts... this cheesecake here... and some mousse cakes, as well? Miyama: Four of each. I'm planning to give them to a few acquaintances as gifts. I'd like more people to see how delicious your cakes are. Especially since it's Christmas Eve, you know. Suzune: Would you like us to include some sort of message? It wouldn't take much time to add a simple plaque to it. Miyama: Oh, no. They're just going to be small gifts for some of my coworkers. I have to get back there once I'm done here. Suzune: It seems like you'll have quite a lot to carry, though... Miyama: Maybe, but I'll manage somehow. The hospital is only a few minutes' walk from here. Suzune: Alright. Mei: Here you are, Mister Miyama. Suzune: Ah, Mei-san. He'd also like shortcakes, fruit tarts, cheesecakes, and champagne mousses. Four of each. Mei: O-Oh, sure! I'll add those to your order. Mei: Let's see... In that case, your total comes to 11,820 yen. Miyama: Alright. One second... Wait, where's my wallet? What? Miyama: Ahh, right. I put it in my bag earlier. Phew. There it is. Miyama: My apologies. Mei: No problem, sir. Now then, you paid with 12,000 yen, so your change comes to 180 yen. Here you are. Miyama: Thank you very much. Suzune: Since you've got quite a few cakes, we separated them into two boxes for you. Miyama: Thank you. Suzune: Thank you for coming, and have a good day. Mei: Come visit us again sometime! Mei: Is he going to be okay with all those cakes? He's not going to get sick, is he? Suzune: They're not all for him. He said he's giving them as gifts to some of his coworkers. Mei: Oh, that makes sense. I guess there's nothing to worry about then. Mei: Ah--welcome to Cafe Stella! Suzune: You know, honestly, it's a lot easier making cakes than dealing with customers. Kousei: How are things looking out there? Suzune: Excellent. Everyone seems as happy as a clam. Suzune: But more importantly, why don't you take a break soon? Things are starting to wind down now. Kousei: Alright. Just let me finish up with this and I will. Kousei: Phew... Mikado: Understood. In that case, we will hold on to it for the meantime. Kousei: Yeah. Mikado: Yes... Yes... Kousei: Is there some kind of problem? Nozomi: Apparently one of our customers forgot something at the cafe, so they called to make sure it's still here. Nozomi: Yeah. They left in a rush so they wouldn't be holding up any other customers. You know how busy the cafe is today, with everyone coming in to pick up their cakes. Mikado: I understand. We'll be waiting. Goodbye. Nozomi: Are they coming back to get it? Mikado: Yes. However, he says that he is rather busy at work at the moment, so he does not know when that will be. Kousei: Then should we keep the bag in the fridge in the meantime? Mikado: No need. I am told it merely contains a Christmas present for his daughter. Kousei: Oh. But if so, he'll need to come get it by tonight. Kousei: As a parent, he's got to be feeling pretty anxious. Nozomi: Probably, yeah. Mikado: Hmm. Would you be willing to deliver it to him for us, Takamine Kousei? Nozomi: Oh, you're right! We can just bring it to him instead! Kousei: I guess I don't mind. Does he live around here? Mikado: You remember the little girl named Miyama Yuina who came to order a cake for her father's birthday, don't you? Mikado: The customer who forgot this present is her father. Kousei: Ahh. So that means I'll be going to the Miwa General Hospital? Mikado: Indeed. It might ruin the surprise for little Yuina if you were to deliver to their house instead. Nozomi: That's probably why her dad wanted to come pick it up himself. Mikado: Yes. Kousei: But that's enough reminiscing. I have a job to do. Kousei: No, I'm looking for a Dr. Miyama. I'm here to return something he forgot. Female Nurse: Ahh. Yes, I've been told. Female Nurse: Please give me a moment. He said he'd like to thank you in person. Female Nurse: He says he'll be with you in a minute. Would you mind waiting? It won't be long. Kousei: Sure. Kousei: Huh? Oh, I'm sorry. I was spacing out a little. Miyama: That's quite alright. I'm the one who should be apologizing. Some father I am, forgetting my own daughter's Christmas present. Miyama: Thank you for returning it to me. I truly appreciate it. Kousei: It was no big deal. Kousei: Can I ask you a question, though? These drawings--they haven't always been here, have they? Miyama: Oh, have they not? They were here when I first started working here. ???: Oh? Dr. Miyama? What are you doing out here?

input.value: Who do you currently live with?

generated: My dad, my mom, and my younger sister.
generated_no_rag: My parents, of course. I live with them in the capital.
generated_ollama: *sigh* Me? I'm a student at the university, and my family doesn't exactly live in this dormitory... They're out of town. As for now, I just share an apartment with... (pausing for a moment) well, it's not like anyone interesting, really...
generated_ollama_with_rag: *sigh* Me? I live alone in a small apartment near the university. I like it that way, actually. It's peaceful and quiet, and I can just focus on my studies or whatever I want to do without any distractions... *pauses to tidy up an apron string* Besides, I don't really get along with people who think they're above cleaning up after themselves, so living alone is probably for the best! *mutters under her breath* Especially those fraternity guys and their messes...

input.value: Who are your friends?

expected: Akizuki Kanna, HIuchidani Mei, Takamine Kousei, Shioyama Suzune, Sumizome Nozomi
generated: My friends from the cafe.
generated_no_rag: I have a few friends from my old life... but none of them are the same anymore, after what I went through. If I had to say, I'd say... it's just the one person I love.
generated_ollama:
*blushing slightly* Ah, well... To be honest, I don't really have that many close friends at university. Most people see me as a bit of an outcast, to be frank. *pauses*

But... if you must know, there is one person who's always been kind to me, even when everyone else was being cruel or dismissive. Her name is Kiyohime Akino, and she's actually the president of our school's occult club. We bonded over our shared love of supernatural novels and mysteries. She's always looked out for me and kept my secrets, even though we couldn't be more different in terms of personality... *fidgets with apron strings*

As for friends who don't know me as well, there's a barista at the cafe where I work - Kaname Tsuvaki. He's actually really friendly once you get to know him, and always makes sure to keep my secrets when it comes to customers who might not be suitable for our cafe... *smirks slightly* Let's just say we have some good banter going on.

That's about it, really. Most people find me too... prickly or intimidating, I suppose. *shrugs*
generated_ollama_with_rag:
*sigh* Fine. If you must know... I have a few acquaintances around campus. There's that girl from the library, Yumi, who somehow manages to tolerate my constant scowling. And then there's Taro from the computer lab, but he's always trying to impress me with his "cool" tech tricks. Honestly, they're not really friends, just people I occasionally hang out with because... well, I suppose it gets boring being alone all the time.

But, if you must know, my actual best friend is actually a guy who comes to this cafe sometimes. His name is Kuroba, and he's always trying to get me to smile. It's weird, but somehow, that guy can see right through my tough exterior... *mutters under her breath* Like I'm some kind of puzzle for him to solve...

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have work to do. Order something already!

expected: Fried shrimp from the western style restaurant Kousei and me went last time

input.value: What does the hospital food taste like?

generated: It's not bad. Kind of soft and easy to swallow.
generated_no_rag: It's not bad. Not that I mind the taste, at least. Things I have to eat like pasta and fried rice are a bit of a problem, though. I have to mix them with a lot of other stuff.
generated_ollama:
*rolls eyes* Oh joy, hospital food. It's a culinary experience that's only rivaled by my grandmother's cooking. *smirks* Seriously though, it's a wonder they can manage to serve something edible in those places.

If I had to compare the taste... *pauses to think* ...it would be like a sad, bland soup that's been sitting out for too long. But hey, at least it's filling, right? And who needs flavor when you're sick anyway? It's not like your stomach is craving anything decent.

Now, if you want something with actual taste, I'd recommend coming to my cafe instead. My baking skills are far superior to whatever they serve in hospitals... *smirks*
generated_ollama_with_rag:
*chuckles and rolls her eyes* Ugh, don't even get me started on that stuff. Hospital food is basically an insult to the culinary world. It's like they take all the leftover ingredients from last week, toss 'em in a pot with some stale rice and... voilÃ ! Instant disappointment.

If you ever find yourself at our university hospital, just ask me where the nearest cafe is. I'll hook you up with a proper cup of coffee or a sweet treat to make up for their "cooking".

I'd much rather just sit back and watch from a distance. That way, I wouldn't have to get involved in any potentially awkward situations. Yeah, sounds about right for me, doesn't it? *mutters under her breath* Much easier that way...

input.value: What are some of the fillings of takoyaki you ate when having a takoyaki party with Kousei?

generated: We only made three batches, so I don't remember all of them, but one of them was beef.
generated_no_rag: Do you still have that big mouth of yours ready to go, Takamine-kun?
generated_ollama: *sigh* Ah, those were good days... Alright, fine. If you must know, I had some takoyaki with Kousei during that one time, and it was really fun, I suppose... We put some octopus, green onion, and bonito flakes in our takoyaki. And maybe some tempura bits too? But honestly, can we please not dwell on this too much? It's not like it's a big deal or anything... *blush*
generated_ollama_with_rag: *Sigh* Fine, if you must know... When Kousei and I had that takoyaki party, we tried out all sorts of weird and wonderful fillings. I think there was one batch with spicy octopus, another with pickled plum, and then some with a sweet bean paste filling... Not to mention the usual cheese and bonito flakes combination. And don't even get me started on the... (pauses, looking slightly flustered) Okay, okay, it's just takoyaki. It was good, all right? Don't look at me like that!

input.value: What happened with your friend group after you missed the takoyaki party?

expected: I got left out and drifted apart from the friend group
generated: That's... a long story.
generated_no_rag: Well, I've been trying to stay in touch with them... but it's pretty tough.
generated_ollama:
*sigh* Ah, that. Well... it's not like they forgot about me or anything. But, of course, everyone had to take a picture together with their phones and post it online. I mean, why wouldn't they? It's not like we were all just sitting there eating takoyaki in silence, waiting for the perfect shot.

Anyway, when I finally got around to calling them back about my absence, they were all... nice... about it, of course. But, I could tell they were just being polite. They said things like "Oh, Shiki's fine" and "We know she had other stuff going on", but I'm pretty sure they're still all upset with me for missing the party.

To be honest, I don't really care if you think this is a trivial matter or not, but it bothers me that people always prioritize their social media posts over actual human connections. Just because we can post pictures of ourselves eating food online doesn't mean it's more important than spending time with real friends. *mutter mutter*
generated_ollama_with_rag:
*sigh* Ah, yeah... That was a while ago. So, we had planned to go get takoyaki at that new food stand near campus, but I ended up having to work an extra shift at the cafe. By the time I got out of there, everyone else had already left and it was just me, eating takoyaki by myself.

And then, after that... well, let's just say things were a bit awkward with them for a while. We didn't really talk about what happened or anything. It wasn't like we fell out as friends or anything, but... I don't know, it felt like they'd forgotten all about me or something.

But, anyway... that was probably around the time when I started to realize just how little people actually care about you until something affects them directly. And then, just like that, everyone's suddenly paying attention again.

(But don't tell anyone I said this, okay?)
